Award.AwardTitle: URM: Undergraduate Research in Computational Biology at UC Merced
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to the University of California Merced (UCM) to establish an Undergraduate Research and Mentoring (URM) program starting in Spring 2011 and continuing through Fall 2015. This program will provide a two-year research and mentoring program in which four cohorts (5 students for first 2 cohorts and 6 students for last 2 cohorts) will receive a combined classroom and hands-on training in a broad array of computational and mathematical biology methods and tools during the summer portions of the program, and then join research projects with faculty mentors in the UC Merced Biological Sciences, Applied Mathematics, and Computer Science programs. The goal of the UCM-URM program is to directly prepare a more diverse population of undergraduate students with the skills needed to pursue and complete graduate studies, and ultimately pursue careers in computational biology and related fields. UCM-URM students will study computational and mathematical biology and develop high-quality research skills that apply critical thinking beyond what is typically achieved in an undergraduate classroom. By the end of their term in the program, students will be well positioned for admission into highly competitive graduate programs in computational biology and related fields. The UCM-URM program will include three main components: (1) a summer training program; (2) two years of independent research, mentored directly by faculty, and culminating in a research portfolio; and (3) ongoing enhancement activities to foster cohort-building and networking, peer mentoring, written and oral communication skills building, ethics training, and career development. Recruitment efforts for the program will be particularly targeted towards groups that have been underrepresented in these fields. Selection into the program and matching with a research mentor will be made according to specific criteria to assure student success. Success of this program will have a significant positive impact on the recruitment of talented undergraduates from diverse populations in California's Central Valley, which has been traditionally underserved by higher education, into biology majors and ultimately into biology related careers. Both quantitative and qualitative evaluation strategies will be used to measure student progress during the two stages of the proposed program, with oversight and advice from an external Advisory Committee. More information is available at http://ccb.ucmerced.edu, or by contacting Masa Watanabe (mwatanabe@ucmerced.edu) or Mike Colvin (mcolvin@ucmerced.edu).

ProgramReference.Text: PROG FOR WOMEN AND UNDERREPRESENT GROUPS

POR.DRECONTENT:
Experience performing research with a faculty mentor can be one of the most enriching experiences for an undergraduate student and many STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Math) professionals cite undergraduate research as a key motivator for them attending graduate school and pursuing a STEM career.  However, undergraduate research can be intimidating or frustrating for students who feel unprepared for their research project or lack a support network of peers to encourage and assist them.  Moreover, students of limited financial means may not be able to participate in unpaid undergraduate research if it means foregoing outside employment.  In January 2011, UC Merced was awarded a grant by the National Science Foundation to establish the Undergraduate Research and Mentoring in Computational Biology (UCM URM) program, with the goal of providing students with the training, mentoring, peer network, and financial support necessary to have a successful undergraduate research experience with a faculty mentor and encouraging them to pursue graduate studies in STEM fields.

The UCM-URM program provided a one or two-year research and mentoring program that accepted 5-7 new students each year.  The program had two components—summer training sessions and academic year research projects.  Each summer the students received 6 weeks of intensive training in the fundamental computer skills for computational biology.  Topics covered in this training included scientific programming in Python, molecular simulations, and data analysis using the R statistical language.  This training program also included professional skill development and enhancement activities.  The topics of these enhancement activities varied from summer to summer depending on student interest and needs, but the topics usually included:  how to apply to grad school; building a network of mentors; how to create an effective presentation; how to ask for a reference letter; and career opportunities related to computational biology and other STEM fields.  Finally, all first year students participated in Responsible Conduct of Research training with the program director, and all students completed an online course that satisfies federal regulations requiring training in responsible conduct of research as part of grant and contract terms.

This 6-week training period was followed by 4 weeks of interviews and rotations with UC Merced faculty in the fields of Applied Mathematics, Chemical Biology, Mechanical Engineering, Biological Sciences, Computer Science, Physics, and Cognitive Science.  At the end of this rotation period students were matched with faculty mentors who would supervise their research during the academic year.  Students who had not graduated could continue for a second year in the UCM-URM program.  These second year students would participate in the summer activities, learning more advanced skills and assisting the new students.

All students in the program received stipends during the summers and academic year to reduce their need to work in outside jobs and allow them to focus on their research projects.  Additionally, the program supported all participants to attend one scientific conference per year, an opportunity which many participants described as one of the best experiences during their undergraduate studies.  The program director had regular meetings of all participants throughout the summer and academic year to discuss their progress and to provide students opportunities to give presentations on their research.

During the entire UCM-URM program from 2011 to 2016, 30 students from 7 different undergraduate majors participated in the program, doing research with 13 UC Merced faculty across many disciplines related to computational biology.  Of these students 25 have already graduated with a STEM degree and the remaining 5 are on track to successfully complete their STEM degree this year.  Of the 25 graduates, 5 are currently in STEM Ph.D. programs at schools including Stanford, University of Illinois at Urbana Champagne, Ohio State, and University of Washington, and 1 is in a STEM M.S. program.  Two of the UCM-URM alumni in Ph.D. programs have received NSF pre-doctoral fellowships and another has received a 5-year Illinois Distinguished Fellowship.  Three of the graduates are in medical school, and one is in a physician’s assistant program.  Additionally, 7 of the program graduates are working in STEM-related fields: 1 is a civil engineer in the Army Corps of Engineers, 4 are working as software engineers, 2 are working at chemical companies, and 2 have earned California teaching credentials and are teaching math in the San Joaquin Valley.  Finally, a number of the continuing undergraduates and graduates currently working are actively applying or planning to apply to graduate school.
